title: Michigan sleep doctor helping Nationals chase World Series title: Goodnight, Max Scherzer
text:
CLOSE Henry Ford Medical Center sleep doctor Meeta Singh talks about athletes, sleep and the Nationals. Detroit Free Press

Dr. Meeta Singh, a sleep expert based in Novi, Michigan, has taken an unusual, behind-the-scenes role in the World Series, setting the bed times for the Washington Nationals.

No, she doesn’t have the full bed-time authority afforded to most parents to say: Turn out the lights, Max Scherzer! I told you to go to bed, or you are gonna get grounded!

But she does give the Nationals detailed recommendations on every aspect of their sleep: How to reduce fatigue when traveling between time zones. When to travel after games to optimize sleep habits. What to do before going to bed. How to become more alert before night games. And when to take power naps.

“It’s similar to how we make sleep schedules for astronauts,” she said. “It’s very precise.”

SCOUTING BEFORE ANALYTICS: Front offices try to find the perfect World Series recipe

GAME 2 DISASTER: Astros confident heading into Washington down 2-0

Dr. Meeta Singh poses for a photo at Henry Ford Medical Center in Novi, Thursday, Oct. 24, 2019. (Photo: Junfu Han,/Detroit Free Press)

At a time when professional sports teams try to gain an edge in any way possible, from studying analytics to employing trainers who work on the body and mind, top organizations leave nothing to chance.

Not even their Zzzs.

“You want to optimize your sleep because that helps you to optimize your reaction time, your accuracy, even split-second decision making,” Singh said. “It helps in preventing injuries and recovering from injury. Really, it helps in every aspect of athletics.”

Sitting in front of a computer at Henry Ford Medical Center in Novi, where she works, Singh bursts with pride while talking about the Nationals, feeling as if she has played a role in how they have gotten to this point, two wins from their first World Series championship. They have a 2-0 series lead over the Houston Astros and will play Game 3 on Friday night in Washington. “It’s exhilarating and nerve-wracking ,” she said.

During the season, Singh sent the Nationals a sleep schedule every two weeks, offering advice in a grid format. “I’d map out what I wanted them to do,” she said. “I would have to sit and look at their game time, look at their travel and then make a schedule out for them.”

During the postseason, her work has increased. She sends the Nationals a new plan every three or four days, even taking into account the team's late-night party after clinching a spot in the World Series.

“What I said to them, ‘Of course, they are going to party,’ ” Singh said. “This is a huge thing. Of course, they are going to be up. But what I’ve always told them: 'On those days, when life happens, and you know you might not get enough sleep, the secret is to get enough sleep beforehand and then playing catch up once things settle down.' ”

Maintaining a routine is the key to all of this. After the Nationals played an afternoon game in St. Louis in Game 2 of the National League Championship Series, the team decided to stay in town overnight to get a good night’s rest on Singh’s recommendation, instead of rushing back and getting home late. Two days later, the Nationals won Game 3, 8-1. “It’s little things like that and the Nationals are really good at it,” Nationals second baseman Brian Dozier said. “It goes to show you that they really care about performance and whatever helps you.”

To get to sleep faster, Singh encourages players to wear special orange-tinted glasses that block blue light, the part of the light spectrum that affects melatonin levels. “In darkness, melatonin is secreted," she said. "That helps you fall asleep.”

So are the Nationals following her advice?

“We tried throughout the course of the year," Dozier said, "but really extensively in the playoffs to really (stick to it)."

Washington Nationals' Brian Dozier, left, congratulates Anthony Rendon after Rendon scored on a single by Ryan Zimmerman off Minnesota Twins pitcher Martin Perez during the first inning of a baseball game Wednesday, Sept. 11, 2019, in Minneapolis. (AP Photo/Jim Mone) (Photo: The Associated Press)

Peak sleep, performance

Singh works with thousands of patients in metro Detroit in her day job. And she got into the sports world almost by accident, working first with the Lions and eventually branching out to help the Red Wings, Tigers and Pistons.

She has given talks at MLB winter meetings, the NFL Combine and the NHL annual meetings. Earlier this month, Singh worked with the Belgium national soccer team before it beat San Marino, 9-0, becoming the first team to clinch a spot in next year's UEFA European Championship. And she offered advice to the Sacramento Kings before they played two preseason games against the Indiana Pacers in India.

“Sleep and recovery are both integral to athletic performance,” Singh said. “The kind of elite athletes I work with are trying to maximize their performance. They are always looking to what they can do and make even a small difference. Wins and losses are based on a small difference. Everybody is trying to do it. The first thing to remember is because sleep as a behavior makes up a third of your day. Making even small changes to that would result in noticeable changes to your performance the next day.”

Singh works extensively with the New Orleans Saints, sending them a schedule every week. “They were really struggling with the games that started at 4:25 in the evening,” she said. “I worked with them over that and they started winning.”

The Saints sent her a game ball, which she finds humbling. “It’s an amazing thing," Singh said. "I am an immigrant. I did not grow up with either football or baseball. It was pretty amazing.”

The New Orleans Saints presented this ball to Michigan sleep doctor Meeta Singh after beating the Miami Dolphins, 20-0, in London. (Photo: Meeta Singh)

She also works with the coaches and support staff. “It doesn’t matter what league it is, the coaches, support staff and athletic trainers, their schedules are much worse than the players," she said. "They get there before and they don’t leave there until after.”

Control and discipline

Singh started working with the Nationals in spring training, when she talked to the team in the clubhouse and spent a day giving advice to individual players. “It was very interactive — there are smart guys on that team, who ask smart questions,” she said. “The skipper was like, ‘Can you send us regular tips on how to sleep?’

“They want to control as much as they can, everything. This team is really disciplined. This is a team that would call me, and say, ‘Tell me exactly what you want to do for the next games.’ ”

She declined to talk about individual players.

But she said many athletes work with her during the offseason, or text her for advice.

Singh gives the players typical sleep advice — sleep in a cold room, don’t use electronics, don’t drink alcohol before bedtime. But she tailors specific recommendations to each player. Like the one who has a girlfriend on the West Coast.

“If there is a player and his girlfriend lives on the other side of America, well, he wants to be on the phone with her for a few minutes,” she said. “This is a guy who should wear those orange-colored sunglasses. So it’s not too much light. He talks to his girlfriend. He can relax and then he goes to sleep.”

As for Singh, these late-night World Series games have been messing with her bedtime. Sometimes, she can't help it. She just falls asleep.
description: A Michigan sleep doctor is setting bed times for the Washington Nationals as they chase the World Series, becoming a key member of the team off field.
